name: Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera)
summary: An adaptogenic herb traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine for stress relief, anxiety reduction, improved sleep, and enhanced vitality.
description: Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera), also known as Indian ginseng or winter cherry, is a well-known adaptogen in Ayurvedic medicine. Its active compounds, called withanolides, are thought to modulate stress responses, reduce cortisol, and improve sleep quality. Modern research supports its use for anxiety, stress, mild depression, sleep disturbances, and physical performance. It has also been studied for potential cognitive benefits and hormonal balance, particularly in men with low testosterone.

metadata.fda_status: Not FDA-approved; marketed as dietary supplement in U.S.

sections.text: Withanolides modulate the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis, reducing cortisol and stress responses. Ashwagandha may also enhance GABAergic signaling, contributing to anxiolytic and sleep-promoting effects. It has antioxidant and neuroprotective properties and may support testosterone production in men.

sections.geriatric: Start at lower doses; generally well tolerated

items: Powder (root powder, commonly in milk or water)

sections.text: Effects on stress and anxiety typically observed within 2–8 weeks. Sleep improvements may occur within weeks of daily use.

other: Avoid during pregnancy due to potential uterine stimulation.
Use caution in thyroid disorders; may increase thyroid hormone levels.
Possible additive sedation with CNS depressants.

items.risk: May reduce effectiveness due to immunostimulation

sections.pregnancy: Avoid due to potential abortifacient effects
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; not routinely recommended
sections.geriatrics: Generally well tolerated; start low and monitor

sections.text: No formal taper required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: One of the most studied Ayurvedic adaptogens for stress and anxiety.
KSM-66 and Sensoril are the most common standardized extracts with different withanolide concentrations.
Has shown testosterone-supporting effects in some clinical trials in men.
